phrases.text: Start by tuning into that little voice in your head. That voice going around in circles, trying to find answers.
Am I doing it right? What if I'm wrong?
Tune into that voice that's always chattering inside.
And slowly visualize it moving down your spine. Getting more and more distant. Getting quieter and quieter.
Moving all the way down to the base of your spine.
Lock in that position. Imagine you can breathe, inspire and expire air from there.
We're going to do three grounding breathing cycles. Imagine you can breathe directly from this point, as if your breath starts right there.
From the base of your spine, inhale for six seconds.
Hold.
Exhale.
Breathe normally. Getting out of your head, into your body.
Second cycle. Inhale from the base.
Taking up more space inside.
Third and final cycle. Inhale.
You're now grounded at the base of your spine. Connected to your inner world.
Shift your awareness now to the sensations that come up around being you.
Welcome the sensations. How does it feel being you?
Do you love being you, the person you are, the life you live?
Welcome any and all sensations. How does it feel being you?
What comes up when you see yourself in this present moment?
Do you love yourself? Do you accept yourself? Are you proud of yourself?
Is there a part of you resisting?
Breathe into these sensations.
Let's go deeper. How do you feel about yourself now, and in the past?
Those younger versions of you.
What versions of yourself do you resist the most? The younger versions you might even hate.
Those versions that ruined everything. If only I didn't say that, if only I did that, my life would be different.
Why? Why did I? I should have known better.
What versions of you seem unforgivable?
Bring them into your awareness. Those versions that didn't know better. That made mistakes.
Visualize them in front of you.
How do you feel seeing them? What do you want to tell them?
Can you forgive them? Entirely?
Haven't you resisted them long enough? Can you welcome them back?
Those versions are you. Welcome the sensations. Let's do a breathing cycle.
Any resistance to forgiving them? Tune into the sensations and inhale.
Let it go.
Breathe normally.
What fears run you and hold you back in life?
The fear of not being good enough. What comes up?
What if I'm not good enough? What if there's something wrong with me?
What if I don't have what it takes?
Allow yourself to feel the sensations.
The fear of being alone. What comes up?
What if no one truly sees me? If I'm destined to be alone, never able to connect without putting up a mask?
What if no one ever gets the real me?
The fear of being stuck. Never living up to your potential. Staying stuck.
Or the fear of being toxic. Did you leave a positive impact on the people you've met?
Can you let go of these fears? Is there any resistance?
Tune into the sensations.
Let's do a cycle. Tune in and inhale.
Let's go one last layer deeper.
Can you let go of the past? Let go of the old you?
Can you turn the page and start a new chapter?
Visualize the old you, that version keeping you stuck. What got you here won't get you there.
Can you thank it? Thank you for getting me this far. But I don't need you anymore.
Thank you, but it's time to say goodbye.
Can you let go of it? The old you. The patterns. The habits.
Can you let go?
What's scary about turning the page?
And what does that look like? Sink into this.
What if things went amazingly well? Tomorrow, next year, the next five years?
What does your life look like? Who are you? How do you feel?
Can you embody this now? Is there any resistance?
Welcome the sensations.
Let's do our biggest breath. Inhale.
Let it all go.
Take a moment to let things slow down.
Let your body relax. Your shoulders.
Detach your tongue from the roof of your mouth. Let your jaw relax.
See how light you can get.
Let your body melt.
Let go of all tension. Your shoulders. Your stomach. Let it melt.
Relax every part of you.
Can you relax even more? Just letting go.
Feeling lighter and lighter. So light you're floating.
Higher and higher. Beyond the mind. Beyond the body.
Letting go completely.
Can you let go even more?
Let yourself melt. Stop controlling.
Just let go.
Floating up so high now. Into this space that comes before everything.
This space of peace. Of abundance. Of authenticity.
Where all is good. All is well.
Where you're exactly where you need to be. Who you need to be.
Where you don't have to impress. You can just be.
This place of ultimate belonging.
Merge with this space. Become one with it.
With every inhale, filling your body with light. Warmth. Love.
Become one with this space. Reconnect.
Feel your body glowing with light. Filled with warmth. Reconnected to love.
Now, gently, from this space of peace...
Bring your attention back to the base of your spine.
Feel this grounding. This connection to the earth.
Start bringing awareness back into your body.
Feel your feet. Their weight. Their warmth.
Feel your legs. Heavy. Relaxed.
Bring awareness into your belly. Your chest. Feel your heart.
Feel your arms. Your hands. The tips of your fingers.
Bring awareness into your neck. Your face.
Feel the top of your head.
Your whole body is now present. Unified. Grounded.
Shift your awareness now. Tonight, your unconscious sent you a message.
Not in words. Not in logic. In images. In sensations. In a language your mind can't fully control.
Your body already knows what this dream is about. Your mind is just catching up.
Bring your attention to where you feel this most right now.
Don't try to change it. Don't try to fix it. Just notice it. Be with it. Breathe into it.
This is where we're going today.
Your dream showed you running. Fleeing. Trying to escape something that was closing in.
Bring your attention to your legs right now. Your hips. Your lower back. These are the parts of you that have been bracing. Ready to sprint. Ready to flee.
How long have they been on alert? How long has some part of you been ready to run?
Welcome the sensations. Don't push them away. This isn't anxiety — this is your body doing what it learned to do a long time ago. It's trying to protect you.
What if you didn't have to run? What comes up when you consider that?
Is there resistance? A part of you that says: no, I need to stay alert. I need to keep watching.
That part kept you alive. It did its job. But right now, in this moment, there is nothing chasing you.
Feel the weight of your body. Your legs are heavy. Your hips are heavy. Let them be heavy.
With every exhale, give your legs permission to stop running. They've been carrying this for long enough.
Let's do a breathing cycle. Tune into the tension in your legs and inhale.
Let it go.
Breathe normally.
Now imagine the scene from your dream. But this time, you stop running. You turn around. And there's nothing there.
What does that feel like in your body? Where does the space open up?
You stopped. And you're still here. You're still safe.
Feel your legs again. Are they lighter? Warmer? Is there less tension?
Whatever your body is doing right now is exactly right. Let it settle.
Let's do one final cycle. Inhale into the space that opened.
You don't have to run anymore.
Your dream showed you stuck. Unable to move. Unable to speak. Unable to act.
That feeling of being frozen — your body knows it well. It's one of the oldest survival responses. When you can't fight and you can't run, the body shuts down. Goes silent. Plays dead.
Bring your attention to your throat. Your jaw. Your shoulders. These are the places that lock first when the body freezes.
What does it feel like there right now? Tight? Sealed? Like something is being held back?
Welcome the sensations. This freeze response isn't weakness. It was protection. It kept you safe when there was no other option.
But the danger that caused this — is it still here? Right now, in this room?
Notice your fingers. Can you feel them? Imagine them gently moving. Imagine tiny movements returning to your hands.
Now your jaw. Can you let it soften? Even slightly? Not forcing it. Just... allowing it to drop. A millimeter.
Every part of you that softens sends a signal to your nervous system: the freeze is over. I can move again.
What would you have said if you could have spoken? In your dream, or in the moment your body learned to go silent?
You don't have to say it now. Just feel the impulse. Feel the words that were swallowed. Where do they sit?
Let's do a breathing cycle. Breathe into the place where the words live. Inhale.
And let them dissolve on the exhale.
Breathe normally.
Your voice doesn't have to come back all at once. But it's coming back. Your body is remembering that it can move. That it can speak. That it can take up space.
Feel what's shifted. Where is there more space? More warmth? More softness?
You are not frozen anymore. Even noticing that — that's movement.
One final breath. Inhale fully.
Let it all go.
Your dream showed you falling. Losing your footing. The ground giving way beneath you.
Bring your attention to your center. Your belly. Your solar plexus. This is where your body holds its sense of stability. Of being anchored.
What does it feel like there right now? Empty? Uneasy? Like something is missing underneath?
This sensation isn't random. Something in your life — maybe something recent, maybe something old — shook your foundation.
How long have you been looking for solid ground? How long has some part of you been bracing for the next collapse?
Welcome the sensations. Even the unsteadiness. It's your body telling you what it needs.
Now, feel the surface beneath you. Whatever you're sitting or lying on — feel it. The hardness. The pressure. The fact that it is holding your full weight without effort.
It's not going anywhere. Feel how it pushes back against you. Gravity is pulling you down. The ground is pushing you up. You are held between these two forces.
You don't have to hold yourself up. You don't have to grip. You can surrender your weight and something will catch you.
Let's breathe into your center. Hands on your belly if you can. Inhale slowly, feel your belly expand.
Long exhale. Twice as long. Let the exhale be the anchor.
Again. Inhale into your center.
Long, slow exhale. Your nervous system is anchoring with every exhale.
One more. Inhale.
Let this exhale carry the tension out. All the way out.
Feel your belly now. Your center. Is it heavier? Warmer? More present?
You are not falling. You are here. Dense. Solid. Held by something older and deeper than any person or situation that ever let you down.
Let that settle in. Not with your mind. With your body.
Your dream showed you in conflict. Fighting. Arguing. Defending yourself against something or someone.
Bring your attention to your jaw. Your hands. Your upper back. Your shoulders. These are the parts of your body that tighten when anger has nowhere to go.
Is your jaw clenched right now? Even slightly? Are your hands tense? Feel into it.
This anger — it's not a problem. It's not something to fix. It's energy. Vital, alive, raw energy that has been locked away because at some point, you learned it wasn't safe to express it.
What would you have said if you could have? What would you have done if it had been allowed?
Don't censor it. Don't judge it. Just feel the impulse. The energy that wanted to move.
Where does it live? In your fists? In your chest? In the back of your neck?
Breathe into that place. Give it space. This energy doesn't need to be rage. It can be presence. Power. Sovereignty. But first, it needs to be acknowledged.
Let's do a cycle. Tune into where the anger lives, and inhale.
Let it go. Not the anger itself — the grip around it.
Breathe normally.
What does your anger actually want? Not destruction. What does it REALLY want?
Respect? To be heard? To be taken seriously? To stop being dismissed?
Those are not unreasonable things. You had every right to want them. You still do.
But you don't have to fight for them anymore. Not like this. Not in your body. Not in your sleep.
Feel your jaw again. Can you let it soften? Even just slightly?
Your hands. Can you open your palms? Let the tension dissolve?
This energy that was rage — what does it feel like when the grip releases? When it's not fighting anymore?
One final breath. Inhale all the way in.
Exhale. Let the fight end. Not because you lost. Because you chose peace.
Your dream carried the weight of loss. Someone gone. Something missing. An absence that your body still holds.
Bring your attention to your chest. Your heart. The space behind your sternum. This is where grief lives. This is where your body closes when the pain is too much.
What does it feel like there right now? Heavy? Tight? Like a door that was sealed shut a long time ago?
This closing — it was intelligent. When love leaves, when someone disappears, your body learns to protect the most vulnerable thing you have: your heart.
But the walls that kept the pain out also kept everything else out.
Do you love being you? Do you love the person you've become?
Is there a part of you that believes you're meant to carry this alone? That love is temporary? That eventually, everyone leaves?
Welcome the sensations. Whatever comes up. Heaviness. Tightness. Even emptiness. It's all valid.
Now, if you can, place your hand on your chest. Feel the warmth of your own palm on your heart.
This is you, holding you. Not waiting for someone else to do it. You.
If emotion comes, let it. If tears come, let them. This is not breaking down. This is breaking open.
Let's breathe together. Inhale into the space around your heart.
Exhale. Let the walls soften. Even a millimeter.
Breathe normally.
A millimeter of opening is enough. You don't have to tear the doors off. Just... a crack. Just enough to let some warmth back in.
Your heart didn't break. It armored. And today, you loosened the armor. Just a little. That's enough for now.
Feel what's different in your chest. Even the smallest shift. That's the beginning.
Your dream showed you exposed. Seen in a way you didn't want to be seen. Judged. Stripped of your armor.
Where do you feel that right now? Is it in your face? A flush of heat? In your belly? A sinking, sick feeling? Or everywhere — this pull to make yourself smaller, to disappear?
This isn't new. This part of you has been carrying this for a long time. Long before this dream.
Most people run from shame. They overachieve to compensate. They numb. They distract. They build a version of themselves that's acceptable enough to never be exposed.
But right now, instead of running, we're going to do something different. We're going to stay.
Can you stay with this sensation? Not to fix it. Not to heal it. Just to be with it.
If this feeling had an age... how old would it be? Don't think. Just let an age come.
If it had a face, who would you see? A younger version of you?
That version of you — the one who felt this first — what did they need? What did they never get?
A look that said: you're okay. You belong. There's nothing wrong with you.
Can you give that to them now? Not with words. With your attention. With the fact that you're here, breathing with them, not running.
Silently, say to this part of you: I see you. You don't have to hide anymore.
I'm not going to reject you. I'm not going to look away.
Let's breathe together. Inhale.
Exhale. Let the contraction soften. Just slightly.
Shame dissolves in the presence of compassion. Not all at once. But enough. One breath at a time.
You showed up for yourself today. You looked at the thing you've been hiding from. And you didn't flinch.
That is the opposite of shame.
This dream keeps coming back. The same scenario. The same feeling. Your unconscious is stuck in a loop, playing this over and over, looking for a resolution it hasn't found yet.
Bring your attention to where this dream lives in your body. You know the place. It's always the same zone. The part that tightens every time this dream returns.
How many times have you woken up from this dream and thought: why does this keep happening? What does it want from me?
Your nervous system isn't broken. It's trying to complete something. A cycle that was interrupted. An action that was never finished.
Let's go into the dream. Not to relive it. To observe it. Like watching a movie you've seen too many times.
See the scene. The setting. The characters. And notice: where does it get stuck? What's the moment where everything loops?
Now. Here's where it changes.
In the dream, there was something you couldn't do. You couldn't run. Couldn't speak. Couldn't open the door. Couldn't reach the person.
This time — in your mind — do it. Complete the action. Whatever your body wanted to do, let it happen in your imagination.
Let this new version settle in. Feel it in your body. What does it feel like to finally complete what was interrupted?
Where does the space open? Where does the grip release?
Now, briefly — go back to the original dream. The stuck version. Feel the tension it creates.
And shift to the new version. The one where you could act. Feel the release.
Original. Tension.
New version. Release.
Your body is learning something right now. It's learning that there IS a way out of the loop. That tension is not permanent.
Let's breathe. Inhale the tension.
Exhale the new ending.
This dream has a new ending now. Not in your head. In your body. Your nervous system felt the exit. And that changes everything.
If this dream comes back, it will be different. Because you are different.
This dream is different. It doesn't carry pain. It carries a message.
Jung called these numinous dreams. Dreams that come from the Self — the deepest, truest part of you. The part that exists before the wounds. Before the patterns. Before the masks.
Most people let these dreams fade by lunchtime. The experience evaporates. They go back to their default state.
Not today. Today, we're going to anchor this experience into your body. So it doesn't just visit. It stays.
Close your eyes. Re-enter the dream. Not as a memory. As an experience.
See the images. The light. The space. Whatever was there. Let it come back fully.
Where do you feel it in your body? The expansion. The openness. The warmth.
Is it in your chest? Your spine? The top of your head? Find the place where this dream lives the strongest.
Stay there. Breathe into that spot. With each inhale, let the sensation expand. Let it take up more space inside you.
This feeling is not something you're creating. It's something you're remembering. This is you — before the armor. Before the fear. Before the world told you to be less.
What does it feel like to be this version of yourself? The version without the weight?
Can you hold this feeling? Not with your mind. With your body. Let it settle into your cells. Into your bones.
If there was a presence in this dream — a figure, a light, a feeling — what did it want you to know?
Don't think. Listen. With your body.
Whatever you received — a feeling, a word, a knowing — hold it. Place your hands where you feel it the strongest.
Breathe it deeper. Into your chest. Your belly. Your limbs.
Let's anchor this with a breath. Inhale this feeling fully.
Exhale. Seal it in.
This dream wasn't an event. It was an invitation. A glimpse of who you're becoming.
You carry this with you now. Not as a thought. As a sensation. As a bodily memory. When the noise of life pulls you away, come back here. It's always available. In the body.
Take a moment to let things slow down.
Let your body relax. Your shoulders. Your jaw. Detach your tongue from the roof of your mouth.
See how light you can get. Let your body melt.
Let go of all tension. Just letting go.
Feeling lighter and lighter. Like you're floating. Beyond the mind. Beyond the story. Beyond the pattern.
Into this space that comes before everything. This space of peace. Of wholeness. Of authenticity.
Where you're exactly where you need to be. Who you need to be. Where you don't have to impress. You can just be.
Merge with this space. With every inhale, filling your body with warmth. With presence.
Feel your body glowing. Filled with something that was always there, underneath the noise.
Now, gently, from this space...
Bring your attention back to the base of your spine.
Feel this grounding. This connection.
Start bringing awareness back into your body. Feel your feet. Their weight. Their warmth.
Feel your legs. Heavy. Relaxed.
Bring awareness into your belly. Your chest. Feel your heart.
Feel your arms. Your hands. The tips of your fingers.
Bring awareness into your neck. Your face. The top of your head.
Your whole body is now present. Unified. Grounded.
Before coming back, one final breath.
You did deep work. Be gentle with yourself today.
I'm going to count from one to five. At five, open your eyes.
One. Awareness rising.
Two. Sensation in your fingers and toes.
Three. Energy returning.
Four. Almost back.
Five. Open your eyes. Welcome back.
Take your time. Have some water if you'd like.
Before coming back, let's take one final grounding breath.
Breathe in deeply.
Exhale slowly.
You did deep work. Be gentle with yourself.
I'm going to count from one to five. At five, open your eyes.
One. Awareness rising.
Two. Sensation in your fingers and toes.
Three. Energy returning.
Four. Almost back.
Five. Open your eyes. Welcome back.
Take your time. Have some water if you'd like.
